title: How do publishers get permission to keep printing a dead author's book? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on how long the author has been dead. If they have been dead long enough, the book is likely in the public domain, and thus anyone can publish it without needing permission. If they are very recently dead, the publisher may have a contract that hasn’t run out yet (the last book I sold was with a 5-year contract. If I died tomorrow, my publisher would still have four years on that contract they could keep, just with giving my next-of-kin the royalties). If neither of the above are true, then they generally need to get permission from the author’s estate (generally under control of the author’s heirs), which can enter into a new contract with the publisher.

The author who has died left his or her royalties to an heir in a will, and that person receives the royalties. If that author has an agent then the agent will renew contracts, or sell contracts on to other publishers, to keep the books in print, and the author’s heirs will keep receiving royalties. If the author died intestate, then the books are called “orphaned”, and the publisher owns the copyright.
